comment: More of a bite than I like, but good

Nondescript, creamy nose with a touch of mint and perhaps a hint of maple syrup and milk chocolate. Deep ochre color. (Neat) Rich, full, and with spice throughout. Oily, sweet maple syrup with bold orange flavors. Dark chocolate. Viscous. Really wonderful and impressive stuff.  The start to finish spice from the proof will make you consider watering down, but do not hide these flavors.  An affordable ($42) treat.

Nose: dried fruit, candy, cherry
Palate: dried fruit, candy
Finish: candy
With water: cotton candy in nose, brings out hint of vanilla on palate
My favorite so far but I’m new to whiskey
warm finish, not a strong burn. Del Frisco's with one big cube.

As most of you probably know, Jim Beam lets people do private selections of Knob Creek barrels. A group of bourbon lovers here in Houston periodically do barrel picks, which a few local liquor stores then sell. This month, they did a barrel of Knob Creek and a barrel of Knob Creek rye. I’m not much of a Knob Creek fan generally, but I heard great things about this barrel, so figured it was worth a try. This particular barrel is #6709, from Jim Beam’s Warehouse E, Floor 4, Rack 18, Tier 3, and was barreled on 3/5/08 and selected on 4/9/18.

Age: 9 years

Mashbill: Jim Beam Standard (75% corn; 13% rye; 12% barley)

Abv: 60%

Price: $42.99 at Rice Fine Wines and Liquor

Setting: Neat in a Glencairn, with two fat basset hounds next to me.

Nose: Heavy Nutter Butters, with some accompanying oak and brown sugar. Potent and delicious, this is one of the best noses I’ve ever sampled. (24/25 points)

Taste: Peanuts, peanut butter, oak, rye. Goes down surprisingly easily for how potent this stuff is, although it does pack some heat. Tastes pretty great. (47/50 points)

Finish: Everlasting. (23/25) points)

Conclusion: This is a fantastic whiskey – easily one of the best that I have ever had. I suspect this would have made a good Booker’s if it hadn’t been selected by the Bourbon Hounds. It has the traditional Jim Beam peanut funk, but dialed up to 11, and in an extra tasty fashion. It’s only real fault is that it is a little one-dimensional, but when the flavor is this good, I don’t view that as much of a fault. All that being said, you have to like peanuts, and if you don’t, this probably isn’t great. I’m a big fan of Nutter Butters, so I’m a little biased towards this flavor profile. I liked this so much, especially for the price, that I ended up going back the next day to grab another bottle, as well as a bottle of the rye. I’m pretty curious to try some Booker’s (which I’ve never had) and see how it compares.

94/100
very spicy, cask strength kicks your ass a little. vanilla, spice and caramel notes. not bad on the follow through, but definitely not a daily sipper. punchy not smooth, but enjoyable.
tasted at cove. a bit spicy
Sweet vanilla light pralines and oak nice and warm and very smooth with a drop of water. Much better than standard knob.

Total wine store pick, rested about 6 months. 120 proof

Nose: caramel, toffee, molasses, honey, slight alcohol burn. 
Added water: I can smell some vanilla now and a faint sweetness.

Palate: immediately hit by alcohol, very warming, and then notes of oak, tannin, and caramel.
Added water: all the same flavors more pronounced now but tasting more tannins and leather.

Finish: fades into more mellow sweetness mixed with cough syrup. 
Added water: finish is a lot more watery which kills that syrupy goodness, but has a doctor peppery taste now.
Very good bourbon. abit hot up front. apple. caramel.

I use to love this bourbon years ago and i moved onto better finds. Still a great low price for bbl proof but its just not as refined as other bourbons north of 100 proof. I drank noah’s mill back to back with it today and lets just say the knob creek is out classed
This was my go to high proof dram before I was introduced to the likes of Weller Antique and Stagg jr. Still can enjoy it but it never leaves me wanting to pour another.

On ice: Nice sweet oak nose with notes of vanilla. Spicey & sweet oak flavor. Dry oaky finish. Sweet oaky lingering finish. 
Twin Peaks single barrel pick.
Scrong. Good. Wish I had it by itself instead of in a flight
This is a great value - if you like high proof and you like sweeter Bourbons, go ahead and pick this one up.

TWCP store pick | 13 years, 8 months
    
    Color: Gorgeous deep copper
    Nose: 3.75 | wet/musty oak, peanuts 
    Palate: 4.25 | there's a lot going on here... rich sweet caramel, vanilla, wet wood, oak, heat and some spice on the finish
    Finish: 4 | long, dry finish
    Price: 4.25 | $40 for a nearly 14 year old bourbon is pretty unheard of
    
    Verdict: Bottle
This tastes its age, lots of barrel influence; definitely a recommend.
Found a 13.5yr barrel at my local liquor store. It’s incredible. Much sweeter and smoother than the everyday KC SB, which is already good for the price. Top notch drink.
The best cask strength bourbon I've ever tried. Great with a splash of water or over an ice sphere.

Knob Creek steps up to the plate and is not playing games here. This is serious bourbon done to near perfection.  Spice, more spice, wood, more wood and even more spice and that classic hot cinnamon is there.  Finish is a mile long
Purchased a handpicked single barrel by Binnys. Aged 14 years. Delicious! Smooth and simple. Not too sweet, not too floral. Great sip
Delicious! So glad it’s not scarce in my area.
Spices, warm but not hot, earthy, not very sweet.
Harsh, but smooth with a honey finish
Not bad, it’s not as smooth as I would have thought it would be for the price.
Perhaps the very best high proof bourbon on the market. I would definitely use this bourbon as an intro for a new comer to high proof whiskeys
13 year barrel pick from condados! thanks Jake
Nose of Cherries, good maple and vanilla on the palate.

Very spicy! With an alcohol content of 120 proof, this whisky leaves tongue burn. However, with its charred oak and very high vanilla content, it's an enjoyable whisky accompanied by hashish or cannibis recently legalized cannibis in Canada!
seems to be spicier with water, more rich and full taste meat without water added.

Knob Creek single barrel store pick aged over 14 years for under $40!  

Enjoyed neat from a Glencairn.  This Beam expression offers a fairly simple nose and flavor profile, but those simple flavors are so rich, mature, and so well balanced.  Sometimes a bourbon doesn't need tons of complexity to be considered great, and that's how I'd describe this one.

On the nose is very rich maple, brown sugar, vanilla, pecan pie, and given the age, a surprising fresh toasted barrel wood scent.  After 14 years I'd almost expect a somewhat musty barrel forward wood scent, but not so.  The barrel is actually more of a secondary note behind the great sweet maple/vanilla combo.  Again a fairly simple nose but very rewarding in the notes it offers.

The palate instantly starts very hot served neat.  A very hot and spicy warming heat, and rightfully so at 60% ABV and I love it; it's lively high spice, wakes your senses up, starts a fire on the tongue, means business.   After the burn comes the rich flavors from the nose.  It offers a taste of exactly what you smell here. Very rich sweet maple, toasted brown sugar, vanilla, spices of cinnamon and clove, and beautifully toasted wood.  Also a nice minty menthol comes on late.  Again not overly complex, but very balanced, so delicious, and rich deep classic bourbon flavors.   Almost bourbon perfection!

The finish lingers a while and is very pleasing, offering more maple, honey, cinnamon, and a more aged wood flavor.  For a 14 year bourbon, I half expected an oak bomb, which I wouldn't have minded anyway.   But that's not the case.  Everything is in perfect harmony here, nothing trying to stand out among anything else.  

Overall for under $40 for a 14 year bourbon that's so well balanced and flavorful, this is hard to beat.  All the classic bourbon flavors are represented here, but amped up to 11 and that's why I love the KC SiB!  That combined with the 120 proof, and it's a heck of a deal for a quality pour.  I'm not typically the biggest Beam fan, normally favoring Buffalo Trace or Turkey products, but the KC has earned a spot in my top rotation for sure!  It's Kentucky Straight Delicious!  Cheers!
One of my favorites to date! I love it with rocks. This one really stands up well to water. Traditional bourbon aroma, lotsa maple oak and vanilla in the taste and aftertastes.
Grabbed a couple of NH store picks. Excellent pour- highly recommended.

Spicy sweet notes slow burn but not harsh 
Excellent

This, to me, seems in the vein of sort of an industry standard kind of bourbon. It's nice, full-bodied, a nice kick of spice, and a little 120 proof burn. Legs on the thicker side, really aromatic nose, I can't see any bourbon drinker being dissatisfied with this bottle. It's worthy of it's price point.

On the nose is dark brown sugar, oak wood, cinnamon spice, vanilla, ginger, rye grain, barrel char, subtle smoke, dried orange peel, cracked leather and cherry lozenges.  The aroma feels very dense and heavy, like it doesn’t want to leave the glass.
-
To the palate it is incredibly hot with a powerful flavour kick at that 60% ABV!  Lots of oak, very astringent, drying on the palate with savory spices, cinnamon and black pepper before sticky brown sugar sweetness arrives with orange citrus oil and spicy ginger with a touch of rye spice.
-
The finish is long with dry oak, leather and tingling black pepper spice accompanied by a pleasant warmth and finally a whisp of smoky char on the exhale.
—
With water added the aromas open up revealing more sweetness.  More approachable on the palate, showing that signature root beer flavour I usually associate with Knob Creek.  Even more dry on the finish, more savory oak.
—//—
Bourbon Mark:  95
—//—
Foolishly, I bottle killed the standard Knob Creek after my review weeks ago, but I did compare them back then.  From memory, I find this one is more richly flavoured and intense.  I really like it!  I think this will replace standard Knob Creek for me.

Barrel #4441
Chuck’s and Red Barn Liquors

For today's Friday dram, I am going back to basics. Back to my style of choice. Well aged high proof Kentucky Bourbon. This particular Barrel is aged for 13 years (Barrel # 7373) and was selected by Fred Noe for Costco AZ. I was shocked at how old it was as I always assumed these single barrel were all 9 years old. However like most store picks, they do vary quite a bit and this is by far the oldest I have sampled from Knob Creek. On to the tasting! 
Right upon entry you are smacked with a big toffee and burnt brown sugar notes that moves quickly to a big cinnamon driven swell. It just about stays in balance for the long oak driven finish. You can literally taste the age. This one wasn't hot at all for the 120 proof. However, with how big the oak and spice swell was, I decided to drop a small ice cube to see how it impacted the flavor profile. As expected, they both recede to reveal butterscotch, Reeces Cups and pecan pie! Much better with ice. Nice complexity. 
I cannot believe I am saying this, but I think this is a little to well aged. 12 years probably would make this a 5 star bottle. As it its just shy of 4. It's the equivalent of a nice batch of Booker's. Cheers all!
rich caramel with a cinnamon and spice to balance out the sweetness, lots of flavor, long oaky finish with a bit of burn
This one grew on me over time.  I like it a lot better with an ice ball!
Challenging for me because of the proof.  Cut with some water, still some spikey alcohol tingle.  Sweet corn.  Buttery biscuits.
sweet and spicy, almost too hot but good

The original is so great, so this one had its work cut out for it. A bit more oak at first sip, still a very nice, smooth taste of vanilla and spice. Very smooth. Nice medium to long finish. I'm shocked this is only 90 points, great nose, taste and finish. I love the newer bourbon brands that push the envelope with ingredients mash bill, and dont copy what was done 150 years ago.  Another truly stellar bourbon from Knob Creek. Its stamped as being specially made for Kroger in Cincinnati.

Had in Kentucky Collins; Knob Creek Barrel Select, simple syrup, lemon, Angostura bitters, Sprite & Luxardo cherries. 
Cherry flavor with tart lemon notes. Tart lemon finish & lingering flavor w/ a touch of cherry.
Asse épicé avec une note sucrée. Explose en début, reste moyennement en bouche. Monte un peu au nez. Notes vanillées et sucrées.
It has a good burn to it, with a splash of water you really discover those flavours hiding in the heat
my favorite mixer bourbon for kentucky mules. proof & flavor stand up to any ginger beer

For the proof, it is certainly a fairly smooth sipper. The main difference I perceive is that this has more wood characteristics than the flagship Knob Creek, probably owing to the 9 year age statement that the other no longer has. There is not a particular quality that I'd write home about, other than being a really robust, effectively barrel strength bourbon for a modest cost. Not in the same league as booker's but then there's  a $30 difference. This is a great guinea pig to test a high proof whisky if you've never had one before.
Significantly better than the standard Knob Creek.
Vanilla and oak tones. Aggressive start. Smoother finish. Pleasant. Bought at NH state liquor store. Would certainly buy it again.

Classic bourbon. It gets huge butterscotch on the nose and palette. Borders on being too sweet, but stays on this side of delicious. I do prefer the Knob Creek single barrel rye however. That is spectacular.

The wine and cheese place pick barrel # 5512

Light cherries and red fruit on nose, spicy mouth, clean sweet finish

Binnys pick barrel 7670

Dark cherries, luxardo cherries on the nose.  Baking spices with pear on the mouth, sweet finish

Knob creek single barrel, 120 proof, 9yr aged
Nose: maple syrup, honey stinger waffle (delicious), snickerdoodle cookies, damp wood

Taste: spicy, warm cinnamon, baking spices, sweet to start but finishes slightly bitter, bitter oak. 

Overall a good pour. Holds up well for 120 proof. I added a few drops of water. I think if I bought this again I’d hold out for a store pick. See how tasty that one was.
Rich, full bodied, spicy and warming as can be.

Toasted nuts and sugary Carmel is rounded out with vanilla and a small amount of oak. Finish is spicy and slightly warm in a very good way.

A small splash in coffee on the weekend makes for a great cup o joe.

Single Barrell selected by Binny's, #7668.. Starting out Neat I sensed notes of caramel come to the top followed by a smokey finish. Even though it has a high proof, the heat disappeared quickly with just a tad bit of ethanol lingering. I prefer an oily mouth feel and it delivered with a nice streak on the glass after letting it swirl then rest. After trying it with a splash of water, I was able to pick up more of the lighter notes, but still maintained a full favor throughout...
definitely taste the vanilla undertones. delayed warmth (which I enjoyed). would recommend trying.
This ain’t no punk.  Hot, peppery, chewy.   This is a man’s whiskey.  I’m almost tempted to add a splash of water which is rare for me.  I’m glad this exists.

I have a generic SiB that’s a 4.25. But, I have a store pic that’s a 5+ and straight up amazing.

The store pic is like a shotgun-blast of peanut brittle and hot peppermint. Exceptionally good juice. 😀👌

My generic SiB is caramel-forward, rich, and hot. Holds up very well to ice (i prefer it with a nice big cube). Not a bad value, especially given the 120 proof. Not as good as Baker’s though.

At 120 proof this spicy bourbon brings the heat, Wow! but vanilla and a touch of sweetness put out the fire. The dark amber coloring and maple aroma are notible. Full and rich flavors are more enjoyable with a lil’ water. IMO-better than Booker’s which is about same proof but more $.
Starks Store Pick. Cost $40. Great value for the money. High alcohol content, but good flavor.  Cinnamon, Vanilla, and Tobacco.
This was a Wells Barrell select 14 years. Good for cocktails and opens up with a little water. Wouldn't purchase again
Best bourbon in its class fiery but opens up if allowed to air for a few minutes
not as smooth as some in this class.

Vanilla and maple sweetness up front, followed by cherry and cinnamon, leading to a long heavy barrel tannin finish. Thick syrupy mouthfeel. Proof noticeable, yet even a drop water kills the sweetness up front and amplifies the spice. Found this really enjoyable after drinking something a little lower proof first, as jumping right into this is a bit of an overload of the tastebuds.

Nose: sugary maple syrup and peppered nuts, vanilla. 

Palate: oily and rich, vanilla, slightly zesty, baking spices. 

Finish: snowballs from smooth spices and sweetness to a decent Kentucky hug.

Nose: sweet with some brown sugar and vanilla. 

Taste: buttery texture. Oak flavor, with some caramel and vanilla. More oak on the back end. 

120 proof but drinks like a 100-110
Exceptional tasting, complex and flavorful; recommend adding a bit of water to really open it up and also make it less difficult on the stomach
Quality bourbon, love single barrels and this didn’t disappoint.  Smooth/Complex for 120 proof.  Better than Bakers by far

As with any new bottle, I plan to return to this to see if the rating improves or goes lower, either way. 

This is a Liquor Barn store pick (Louisville, Kentucky, 14-years-old, barrel 6375, “Blue Rose Special”)

Nose: I expected an oak bomb and did not receive the oak bomb. At 14-years-old, this does not have a ton of oak on the nose. I got brown sugar (possibly maple sugar as is commonly reviewed), leather, and dark fruits. There was oak, but in the background. 

Palate: muted baking spices, vanilla, cola, butterscotch.  

Finish: shockingly moderate for a 120-proof whiskey. Finished a bit oily and like a lower proof bourbon.
I think this is the same bourbon I'm drinking. It has a strong bite but good flavor.

I am a bit disappointed in my first pour from this bottle.  I am a big Knob Creek fan but this seems a lesser drink than the regular small batch.  A splash of water seems to do very little.  I have high expectations of higher proof single barrel offerings to bring assertive flavors and bright textures.  This misses the mark.  I am hopeful that this is from a weak barrel or maybe it just needs some time to air out a bit.  I will give it another go in a few weeks.
Still the Beverage Cellar store pick.

Store pick - barrel from floor 2 and aged 14 years!  Nose is vanilla and brown sugar.  Taste hits the front of the tongue with a tang reminiscent of something salty.  Oak comes through on the taste.  Maybe some dill like a rye.  Loooong finish with a leather note.

taste.... amazing for a high proof
nose.... see previous comment except replace high proof with 9 year! Finish... Longer than John Holmes!!

Coming back to this 14-year store pick (Liquor Barn, KY)

Nose: sweet corn, leather, some oak

Palate: rich with nutmeg, vanilla, orange, cola

Finish: rich and peppery but the bite is not what I’d expect from a 120-proof

You might be tempted to dash water and open this up (and proof it down a bit) but based on the pours I’ve had so far, watering this below probably 105-110 proof and it loses its complexity and richness significantly. Just keep it neat with a few drops, and small pours ;)

Nose sweet, lots of brown sugar
Spicy palette, nice strong 120 proof.
Finish has lots of oak and cinnamon.
Store pick I have is great. Rich
Fantastic nose of vanilla and peanuts.  The palate is full bodied and matches the nose with an excellent oak finish.

Nose:  Vanilla, corn, oak spice, sweet, maple, cotton candy
Palate:  Alcohol heat is pretty intense.  Thick mouthfeel, spicy, sweet, vanilla, maple syrup
Finish:  long finish, spicy, dry, sweet 
and vanilla
A very well made and complex bourbon.  While the alcohol heat is a little intense, it is still surprisingly smooth for 120 proof.  A little bit of water tames the heat and still maintains most of the complexity.  this particular bottle was barreled on 10/15/04 and bottled on 8/3/18.

Perfectly balanced sweetness and oak up front. Finish is smooth and bold but a little too short for my liking. 

14 year old store pick. Barrel #6508 selected by NH.
This store pick is from Keg's phenomenal. Great pour neat or on ice. Cream corn, vanilla. Very spicy yet smooth for a 120prf pour.

Nose: Carmel, lemon peel, oak
Spicy, oak on the front. Finish is hot, heavy oak

Best bang for the buck under 50 bucks. I could just smell this one all night long. I like a little water with this as it tones down the slight 120 proof burn, but it's great straight also. Vanilla, maple, and spice is quite nice :)
Holy barn burner!  Be sure to add water. Once you do it is tolerable. However, not my favorite. Ok at best.

Neat.  Party Source store pick.  Most dark notes on the nose.  Caramel, oak, char.  Quite oily in texture.  Char and sugar on the tongue.  Gives way to more high notes on the taste.  Vanilla. Orange.  Cinnamon but a sugary cinnamon.  Berries on the back end.  Very nice store pick!

Barrel #6240 | Enzo’s Hideaway | Disney Springs

Spices and brown mustard on the nose. Heavy spice palate, oak on the finish.

Binnys store pick, about 14 year barrel.
Aroma: caramel and oak
taste: huge amount of oak! spices and brown sugar finishes with some vanilla.
excellent for the price
For knob creek, it was pretty tasty. Don’t mind this juice at all.

Warm!
Nice lingering taste of spices.

Vanilla spice and everything nice?
But beware the burn and tingles!

Delicious and makes you want to go back for more!

Nose is warm caramel, vanilla, oak, with a touch of smoke. Initial flavor is brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon. Not hot, but definitely spicy. A small addition of water didn't change it much. Nice oaky dryness and old leather on the finish. Not overly complex, but sips well for a 120 proof.

Appearance: Rich amber color. Seems to have high viscosity.
Aroma: Oak, nutty, Macintosh apple
Taste: Matches aroma closely. Oak, smoke, fewer fruit flavors, some cherry and vanilla 
Finish: Long, char flavor lingers, earthy.
Last of my Beverage Cellar pick. It was as good a sip as ever!

Nose: classic charred oak, vanilla, slight ethanol
Palate: maple syrup, smooth, leather
Finish: looong, heat, oak, baking spice
Great flavor, strong notes, I do add a few cubes and two cherries (prior bourbon soaked) into my small Yeti...love it....I have the Party Source NKY store pick with extra 4 years.

Barrel Select store pick
Liquor Barn (KY)
Age: 14 years

Nose: the age on this bourbon really dampens the proof with a rich, semi sweet aroma that includes dark fruits, candy corn and pleasant aged oak 

Palate: rich with vanilla, baking spices, hints of buttered bread and nutmeg 

Finish: spice and proof does come up here, but pleasant. Oak returns on the finish. Some zesty citrus too. 

Despite the age of 14 years, this store pick is well balanced, not too oaky, a bit spicy, but enough sweetness to spread things out. It consistently beats Bookers for me, but your mileage may vary.

Nose: Cherry, Vanilla, Red Apple, Nutty, Brown Sugar, Oak

Taste: Cherry Shortbread Cake, Brown Sugar, Oakey

Cinnamon toast and nutmeg on the nose, smooth and sweet red hots on the palate, long spicy finish. Its all pretty intense. A splash of water  toned it all down a little. I required a second splash of water, which brought out some maple sweetness on the nose and palate and made the finish more enjoyable.
Vanilla and Spicy Cream with a kick.
Rich, dark caramel and vanilla notes. Very easy drinker for BP bourbon. Long finish. This batch aged 14 years as a store select.
Spicy w vanilla and oak neat.  Good juice.
A lot of vanilla and oak, with a good burn. Very good with a splash of water. Great drink for the price.
I taste vanilla and weirdly, peanut butter?  It’s really fantastic.
splash of water makes it nice 👌
Very woody - needs time time to open

Packed with flavor and finishing burn

Store pick. 14 yr
Definitely 120 proof. Over ice, has a Caramel taste on the palette and finish

Rocky’s Pick #2 “Orange Creamsicle” 9yr

Vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg on the nose. Huge vanilla, citrus, oak. Crazy long finish.
Flavorful. A lot of hot alcohol in the finish.
Very forward spice. A couple drops of water cool the heat and bring the fruity aroma out.
Good, but Elijah Craig-12 is better
Very nice spice. Enjoyed this with an ice cube to calm down the heat. Good drinker
splash of water or club smooths it out perfect, happy 4th!

Vanilla, oak, fruit, liquorice,
Connor - asbestos

Wasn't sure about this at first, but have really come around to it. Definitely needs water and air. Let it sit for a few moments before sipping.

Heavy cinnamon burn up front, which dissipates into a gingerbread-like sweetness. Finish is medium, not quite hanging around until the next sip.

Decent bourbon, just a bit hot.

Setup: neat in a Glencairn rested for 10min.

Nose: Toasted Oak and Leather with hints of vanilla underneath. Nothing overpowering.

Palate: Pepper and oak upfront. The longer you hold it, the sweeter it gets. Notes of vanilla and syrup pop. Warm going down. Great sip overall.
My wife’s favorite everyday bourbon. Spicy, but balanced.

High alcohol makes it tough to let this chill and develop on the palate without guzzling some water to ease heartburn. I guess I have met my match in high proof whiskeys. I hate to say it, but just a mist of water makes this open up better. True to Jim beam/ knob creek/ baker beam line this is a unique one if you like sweet, spicy and burnt corn / leather taste. Nice to have on the shelf as an alternate flavor profile profile to popular Buffalo trace whiskeys or high rye whiskeys
Big notes of vanilla, nuts, Carmel, spice and oak. At 60 abv you probably want a little water. If you can get it for $50 or less, it holds its own against other Jim Beam small batch products.
Caramel sweetness which leads into a long cinnamon after.

Strong vanilla nose. Packs some serious heat on the palate, yet quite bearable for something this high proof. A few drops of water can unlock some of the subtler notes for those not used to the heat. Lots of spice and oak (but not overwhelming), some toffee and raisins too. Long lasting finish. Great choice for someone looking to move up from small-batch Knob or similar bourbons - and you can find it in stock too. Just brilliant overall.

Prominent cherry note on the nose along with oak barrel. The palate is oily and tastes like cherry cough syrup with some baking spices, vanilla, and a coffee cake thing. Pretty hot but drinkable without water. I prefer it with a few drops of water. The water being out the cherry and baking spices. At first I was a little turned off by the cherry cough syrup note but have grown to enjoy it as I haven’t had that prominent of a cherry note before. This is a barrel pick from Gresham Liquor Store  and I have not seen cherry mentioned much in reviews for the whiskey. Guessing I may have gotten a bottle from a special barrel :)
Sweet cinnamon flavors.  Long, hot finish.
Spicy and warm. A little more cinnamon, oak, and tobacco after adding a few drops of water. Found it for $29.99 and cleared the shelf

Very mellow for 120 proof. Much sweeter than I anticipated. Vanilla, oak, maple, and tobacco describe the palate. The nose was calm for the 120 proof. Would recommend for a good high proof bourbon. Great entry bourbon in this category.
Warm and full. It has spice and it has sweet. Nice well rounded bourbon.

750ml poured neat into Glencairn at home.  Nose is full of spice, with cinnamon, vanilla, clove, some heat.  Taste is more spice, black pepper, red hots, mild oak, apricot.  Lingering spicy finish.  Maybe a touch too much spice interaction here, but not too hot and has a nice mouthfeel.  Like.  

Add a couple drops of water: evens out the spices, really brings the individual flavors to the fore.  Finish is till long and spicy, touch of heat lingers.  Nice.  9/4/19.

Tasting and nosing this neat was a little too hot for me personally though not unpleasant. I’ve experienced big changes in palate when adding a little water but this is the first time I’ve seem dramatic changes in the nose as well. It’s like turning the key to a locked treasure chest. Now it was a well balanced mix of vanilla, oak, spice, maybe a hint of cherries and a whiff of saltiness much like an ocean breeze.
An all around great bourbon!

Neat from a Glencairn glass. 

Beautiful amber color reminiscent of the Jurassic Park amber. 

Oak, vanilla, ethanol, leather and ball park peanuts on the nose. 

Strong oak up front on the palate with cinnamon, vanilla and salted peanuts. 

Long finish with palate carrying through and a nice Kentucky hug. Smooth, sweet heat and barrel spice take you home. 

One of the best bourbon values; an age statement and high proof.  And one of the few I like to add a small ice cube.

The nose is fruit and oak.  On the palate I get quite a lot of spice, butter, and apple.  This is very hot without water, but not in a bad way.  It's hard to identify the heat.

With a splash of water, the nose opens up a bit showing caramel and spice, wood, and perhaps a light hint of vanilla.

The butter and spice is even more pronounced with a splash of water.  It's still hot, but the hotness is more cinnamon and pepper than ethanol.  The apple is still present but I get a bit of char and rye now.

I definitely get a lot of ethanol on the nose of this high-proof juice. Hear me out on this: I also get a little strawberry Twizzler. On the palate, bourbon: light cinnamon, oak and vanilla. It’s just more full than most bourbons that have a similar flavor profile. The Belle Meade was more complex tonight, but this is a heck of a sipper.
Spicy, vanilla, sweet and smooth; although not too complex.  Easy to sip considering the 120 proof!!  No ice needed. Fantastic single barrel option.

Nose: sweet with notes of vanilla, maple, corn, and spice even with the higher proof not presence of ethanol

Palate: rich vanilla, oak and spice that coats your entire tongue

Finish: spicy and slightly sweet that is long and gave me my first “Kentucky Hug”

High proof but would be a really good sipper. 
[Longhorn Steakhouse Single Barrel pick]

After all the amazing reviews and ratings I snagged a bottle. This is some serious cask strength bourbon! Poured neat, clingy glass coat. Nose isn't as strong as I would have expected. Ethanol is present but muted. Has maple, leather, dusty caramel, varnished hardwood and wet leaves. Some rye notes come in after resting including some pleasant dill. Palate is bold oak soaked with thick maple caramel, cashew butter, candy apple, vibrant heat(not harsh) and robust spice. Wonderful heavy damp musky note throughout. Deep and complex with great balance of sweet/spicy with plenty of barrel at 9 years. Long lasting finish of melting caramel and strong musky oak with spicy cinnamon. I find the delivery less of a bomb going off like some high proof whiskey. Its more like a locomotive, once it gets going it cant be stopped powering through to finish. This is the most scotch like bourbon Ive had with the exceptional range and nuance of flavor. I had high expectations for this and Im not disappointed. Well worth the $42 I paid............95/100....fantastic bourbon, buck twenty yet smoooth.....dropping in some H2O opens the nose and blossoms the flavors or stick to neat and enjoy the heat.......I agree with everyone else, anyone that enjoys bourbon needs to try this heavyweight
Very sweet on the nose, high vanilla,  smoother than expected,  strong even burn
Pretty good, but it's so spicy it makes me cough on the back end. I like spice, but this made me decide I don't like it in my whiskey. I'd give it a better score if it wasn't for the spicy finish.

Waited to thin the herd down a bit before opening this one. Picked up at Walmart liquor store for $40ish if I recall. 
Smell is sweet, deliciously sweet. First taste tells me standard knob Creek flavor profile. No complaints so far. Mouthfeel is a bit warm since it is 120 proof I’m not surprised but it’s not overwhelming either. Goes down well for the proof also. I really like what I’m tasting here. Outstanding bourbon for a non-allocated item and an age statement on the bottle too. I feel for the price point I’d certainly go back to this one again. 
As a tasting note I also added a small cube to open the flavor profile and bring the proof down and it worked wonders. I’m thoroughly impressed with this one. Thanks KC for putting out readily available bourbon that doesn’t taste like crap.
A spicy bourbon with plenty of Carmel and vanilla to even it out. The spice is mainly cinnamon and for a spicy whiskey I thoroughly enjoyed

Nose:
Vanilla, oak, vanilla bean ice cream. Hint of cinnamon, baking spice, milk chocolate
Palate:
Rye spice, oak, honey
Finish:
Medium, Drying oak, cinnamon, grassy, spice
Pretty tasty, but the finish is too damn spicy for my taste.
Better after it rests a bit.

Hot but very good. 

Just enough sweet but a god about of spice to balance out a nice 9 yr.
NH Liquor and Wine Outlet pick, barreled 3/11/08, selected 4/27/18.  Barrel #6517, floor 6, rack 45, tier 1
Redstone Barrel Society  pick, aged 14 years 8 months
Enjoyed this one neat though was really nice and smooth on the rocks. Helped chill out the high Proof.
Flavor is stringent. Needs more caramel overtones.

OK so another Knob Single to review.  10/14/2004 to 2/5/2019 so 14+ years old.  Party Source pick.  

Nose - I get a light fruit, some saw dust, cherry wood, and alcohol esters.  You might notice some bourbon notes missing.  A drop of water and this things pops open and unlocks the classic bourbon notes.  There a funk and hay and barn like note here too.  A touch of savory. 

Taste - Butter, toast, vanilla, oak...oh and a really rich butter on the finish.  A second taste and I'm getting more of the classic bourbon vanilla and caramel and oak.  It's lively and explosive in flavor but there's this buttery note and it's even in the mouth feel.  Water brings out old leathery bourbon and the butter leaves the foreground but remains on the finish.

This is very much an off profile knob creek and it's wonderful bourbon.  I'm going 3.75 but I seriously considered a 4.0.  But lets save that for exceptional whisky and not just my favorite Knob Creek to date.  I will note that at 45 bucks the value here is insane and this is why I recommend people try as many knob creek single barrels as they can.  Even the non store picks can be exceptional and I really do mean exceptional.

So a store pick this will be Gallenstein Selection #16 coming in the new packaging.  2/10/2004 to 2/7/2019 so we're about 15 years old here.  

Nose - It's sweet, rich caramel yes, but brown sugar, some cinnamon, creme pie, custard, vanilla.  Oh there's even some chocolate here, it's big, it's dark.  There's strong evenly balanced finished oak.  I'm not getting 15 year old notes here, the oak is a bit more raw than a really old aged wood but still there's some age here.  We end up with a nice balance between oak and sweet really really good.  Water tames the oak and brings out the nice vanillas.  

Taste - Opens with a nice sweet note but quickly turns into dusty oak and then nutty notes, then in the finish some spice and then a funk and oak and yet there's still a nice sweet element.  A drop of water pushes the vanilla out just like it does in the nose.  Very oak forward still and really complex oak.

I have done this blind with ECBP A119 and I picked this over it.  I'm not a huge blind fan as sometimes one whisky makes another taste better and it wouldn't be that way without the head to head.  Still this one holds up well.  It's not as sweet and it has more oak notes.  It is much more complex and has more transitions and nuances.  I can however see some off notes.  

3 stars, a fine dram and I know this single barrel is likely gone, but with any single barrel batch variation is life, not just store picks.  This is better than any bookers will ever be (maybe not a 30 or something like that) so take that with what it is worth (I'm not sure I'll ever review a bookers as I don't generally care for their quality to price).

Nose: Brown sugar, toffee.   Buttery, bready biscuit. Pepper.  Fruity, slight banana.  Maraschino cherry.  Cereal grain.  Cardamom, clove.

Palate: Brown sugar.  Buttery biscuit.  Black pepper.  Bright fruit.  Peppermint in the very back.  Beautiful perfume fueled by alcohol.

Notes: this is the one that started my journey.  Big, bold, flavorful.  An easy pick for me.  If I could, this would be my daily drinker.
Excellent. Pure caramel with vanilla on the finish. A slow pleasant burn that sits with you but never flares up.
You can taste the vanilla and pretty heavy oak tones. I found it a bit too spicy on the harsh side. Not going to be a favorite for me.
Flavorful, easy drinking bourbon; especially for 120 proof.

N: hint of sugar, expo marker, campfire
P: leather boots, cowhide, peppery, anise 
F: slow warming burn, leather

N:  Darker, leather, oak
P:  Buttery, peppery, spicy, black cherry, leather
F:  Long

Single barrel Select by Binnys, barreled 1/20/10 picked 5/24/19. Barrel #9041. Warehouse W-L, floor F-06, Rick R-010. 
Fruity and just hot enough at 120, I was skeptical they didn’t leave at BP, but this is just right. Blackberries, bramble, Rye spice, creamy, for the money I love it to be frank. Do I like ECBP more, yes, but this to me is akin to the flavor profile but more berries. This bottle will please those who like ice cubes and those who like neat heat alike.

Nose: Vanilla, oak, brown sugar.  Classic bourbon.  Char.  Citrus.  Ethanol is helping everything jump out of the glass.  Dark fruits, peaches, strawberries, cherries, banana.  
Slightest rye space.  Peanuts.

Palate: Immediate brown sugar and oak, vanilla, tannin, char.  Bold without being overbearing.  The 120 proof shows up bigtime.  Fruity complexity dances around - strawberry, banana, peach, cherries, stone fruits.  Long, pleasant finish with bursts of sweet floral character.  Slightly buttery biscuit-y thing going on in there.

Other notes: This is still an amazing drink.  Spot on price:quality ratio.  I could get lost in this stuff for a long time.  Definitely one to respect - also shows you just how much of a difference 20 proof makes - compare against regular Knob Creek and you get a great lesson.  This is a bottle I always make sure to have on hand.  Objectively it's not perfect - it can be a little harsh and powerful at times, and there are some deficiencies in the overall balance.  That being said, it's almost perfectly aligned with my palate and preferences.

Barrel #7632
Hand selected by Discount Liquors.

Missouri 
Warehouse: W-I
Floor: F-03
Rick: R-021
Barreled: 2/27/2004
Selected: 6/25/2019 (15 years, 4 months)
Quite powerful! Great flavor and finish. Overall solid high proof bourbon
15 year now in 2019, good bite but smooth enough for a 120 proof

On the nose, the classic Beam flavors are coming through.  They aren't as rich or rounded as other Beams like Baker's and Bookers.  Nonetheless, it is still quite good.  This isn't something I'd drink everyday because of the high proof, but flavors are good for the price.  However, there really isn't anything about it that makes it special.  Don't get me wrong; it's very good, just not very memorable.

This particular bottle was purchased early 2019 from Liquor Barn in Lexington.  The plaque states to be a 14yr barrel rather than the 9yr on the printed label.  Bottle has been opened twice since then and put back due to the bear-spray like sensation it left me with.

The color is dark amber but the nose is a little off putting for me but likely not for all - roast peanuts and toffee.  There is also some warm vanilla and pepper - and ethanol astringency.  The fumes make my eyes water if I get close enough to the glass... I’m thinking 120+ proof if that’s possible.

Oh the burn!!!  White pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg?  Leather whip to the face.  Vanilla in the background.  I don’t think I should breathe near open flame.  

Looking back at the legs they practically don’t move.  By this point some of the toffee and vanilla are coming back up my sinuses and the oak and leather sit on the back of my tongue.  

2 drops of water - a move I rarely take.  Vanilla toffee bomb!  Now we’re talking.  The burn is still there but more balanced with the oak and leather notes.

I’ve never had Stagg Jr but I can’t help but wonder if these are similar... time to hunt.

Nose: pure sweet oak, vanilla, slightly fruity
Palate: deep smoky tea herbs
Body: thick and smooth
Finish: slow long warming finish. Tiny bit of leather at end

Final number: 91
Damn near perfect in every way. Complex nose, layered flavors, viscous mouthfeel, beautifully modulated finish.  This is the whole package.
Way too hot for me. Needs water and air
For the price, this is great.
Has quite a bite to it, little to no after taste

11 year barrel selected from LeNell’s Beverage Boutique.

Carmel nose.
Spice and vanilla on the palate.
Nice medium finish.
Tastes like roasted pecans and vanilla. Really good

Day 6 of my bourbon advent calendar

Nose: Starts with a pleasant oak, and vanilla, and just a slight astringent ethanol smell, but it's not overwhelming.

Palate: Coming in at 120 proof it does drink like it, but with a dash of water a sweet vanilla and cinnamon sugar.

Yet another high proof bourbon, and it's fantastic. It is a very plain bourbon in comparison to some store picks, but it will suffice till my local liquor store gets a barrel.
Smooth for 120 proof. The burn is there but not unpleasant. A few drops of water or an ice cube opens it up

N(4.25): love the smell. It opens up a lot more after a couple of minutes. Surprised no alcohol punch. Oak, red berries, peanuts, plum, citrus at the end of a big sniff. 
P(4.25): first taste was hot first sip of the day. Sweet bomb of all types of sweetness. Fruit, brown sugar. Pins and needles on the tongue with a boat load of baking spice and vanilla on the end
F(4.25): very long butter oak taste with a deep Kentucky bear hug. Creamy vanilla has a medium length combined with a dash of whip cream sweetness. 

Totally bang for your buck. I’m going to hunt for a store pick. When this runs out, I’m replacing it right away. Can’t beat the value for price.

All the deep wood and subtle sweetness of the standard label, kicked up by the proof. Brings out a ton of spice that mingles with the oak, and enough richness to carry both. Love the heat and the balance, damn near perfect.
Actually K&L pick 8/19 barreled 10/20/04. Rich caramel/toffee and vanilla that opens with water.
GNS store pick. Nice vanilla and spice nose with a finish to match.

Nose: maple and sugar with lots of oak

Taste: maple and caramel up front, smokey oak and bitterness/spice on the end 

Finish: sweet and oakey with a lingering spice.

Deep, rich color. Spruce, menthol, cardamom, and caramel apple on the nose. Viscous mouthfeel and not too vapourous for the proof. Some fruit leather notes on the front palate is balanced out by a cinnamon spice finish. 

Wasn't crazy about it at corkpop, but about 20% into the bottle it really calms down and is a bold, spicy, dessert.
Good burn. Intense heat on the swallow. Smooth going down. A subtle hit of vanilla at the very end. Great Bourbon for being 120proof very drinkable.

This is a 9yr Single Barrel Reserve store pick from Discount Liquor in Nashville, TN. I have another pick from this store that is pushing 15yrs and is fantastic. Let’s see how they did ok this one.


The nose has freshly baked sweet yeast rolls leaping out with vanilla, oak, dark cherries and rye.

The palate is semi-sweet with oak, leather, dark cherries, brown sugar, corn and some rye.

The finish is nice and long with dark cherries and oak lingering, with the sides of the tongue tingling.

This is very good. Discount Liquor is now 2 for 2 on the KC Single Barrel picks. This is uniquely different than the almost 15yr old one that I have. Both are great! These have to be the best deal in bourbon for Barrel Proof Single Barrels.
Smooth. Flavorful. This is a hidden gem. The finish reminds me of Angels envy cask.
Surprise of the day.  Delicious, good nose, good heat and flavor.  Adding this to my list!
Solid and drinkable. On the heavy side, less wheat and more oak.
This will spice up your life. The 120 has a bite to it so I like to enjoy with an ice cube. But this is worth a spot in the shelf.

Floral sweet start 
Alchohol heat finish 
Definitely add water

Starts off spicy, with a warm vanilla, followed by maple at the end.  Adding a splash of water tones down the spice and brings out the sweeter flavors a bit more, especially the vanilla, and adds a caramel undertone.
Best single barrel for the price.  Full robust flavor w complex finish.  Very smooth w no heat

Typical golden color slightly on the darker side. Legs are skinny and not as viscous as I would expect from a 9 year old bourbon, likely due to higher proof. Nose is strong but none too harsh, spicy and oaky, with limited sweetness. On the palate, 120 proof hits hard but is surprisingly smooth. Quite spicy, vanilla is much more prominent now. Finish is beautifully long, slow, and warm. As a rye whiskey lover, this is a fantastic bourbon with similar characteristics. Combining the low cost, high ABV, and complex yet smooth flavors, this is great bang for your buck.
Loved the 120 proof. It’s full bodied and a great pour considering how conservative the price is. Can definitely taste the oak and maple and is good to just sip on.

On the nose I'm getting bits of peanut and oak. But a tremendous amount of bubble gum. 
The bubblegum not translates to the palate as well, I'm not sure if it was from what I ate earlier but this crazy sweet note.
Nice amber color in glass. Nose - sweet, slight oak, and leather. Taste - strong with slight burn and long finish of oak and sugars.
A little alcohol flavor that takes over. Mild sweetness, but just ok.

So much oak, maple, spice and char, a little hot smelling but didn’t follow in palette 

Palette gave me shivers, spice both barrel and rye hit hard. vanilla, red fruit sugars oak and char

Finished with choke cherry dry and sweet.

Nose: excellent chocolate caramel. 
Palate: extra ice or water due to proof. High in spice content. Not quite as good as the nose but complex, rich and sweet with a long finish

Total Wine pick
W-L
F-06
R-10

Dark amber in the glass. Strong ethanol on the nose that gives way to a little caramel after letting it breathe for 10 minutes. A good pour. Tasted right after Baker's and I liked Baker's better though it's hard to say why. There's just not a lot here that stands out.

Revisiting this with a more complete review picture.  I'm a Knob Creek fan.  I started drinking the original 9 year 100 proof sometime in 1993, right after it was released.  It was love at first sight.  I've been a scotch head since the 80's, with a side deal with Canadian whiskies.  I never really cared for bourbon much. My best friend was wholly committed to Maker's Mark at the time and, frankly, that wasn't my jam.

Fast forward 25 years.  After being less that impressed with the NAS 100 proof I'd stopped drinking it.  Honestly I  didn't notice that loss of the age statment. What I noticed was that it just didn't move the monkey anymore. And if you're a whisky-head then you know that damn monkey had better be dancin' or you're out buying a fresh bottle of something.  And through some bizarre law of physics, something is never less expensive than the last thing...  

Its not like KC became bad, but it just didn't sparkle anymore.

Then I found a 9 year old, 120 proof single barrel masterpiece.  It had been released because... and get this... evidently a bunch of folks like me had just lost interest in Knob Creek. 

And you know what? 

Love again!  

AND THEN I HAD A STORE PICK THAT WAS TRULY EXTRAORDINARY!.  

Holy corn juice, Batman!  That bottle got the monkey break dancing!

This is one of my "core selections".  

These are the bottles I could enjoy forever.  

Knob Creek Single Barrel, Wild Turkey Rare Breed, Old Grand Dad 114, George Dickel Bottled in Bond, and Evan Williams Single Barrel.  

The WT and KCSB are tied for first in my heart.

This KCSB is sweet, complex and sophisticated.  I don't need to list what it tastes like or smells like. Go get a bottle! THIS is what great bourbon tastes like!

Ordinarily I'd say this is a solid 4. That is to say it's top 20% of every bourbon I've ever had.  Better than 4 out of every 5.  And I'm standing by that.  Keep that damn BT or ER, I'm drinking this.  

And once in a while, because this is a single barrel and they have some variability, you get a bottle that just satisfies.  Its delicious. It checks all the boxes.  Strong. Sweet. 
Complex.  Aromatic. Full flavored. There's just nothing more you can ask from a $45 bottle.  

I'm having a generous pour from a bottle like that right now.  With chocolate covered strawberries.  And my wonderful wife of 40 years next to me. How good does ice cream get? 

And so I ask you; what more can one want from a whiskey?
Excellent, vanilla and oak nose. Full bodies mouthfeel with a nice loooooong burn.

This highlights the sometimes vast differences between store picks and the standard offering.  The Total Wine in Charleston has had three different store picks of this, and they've been consistently very good. That consistent goodness prompted me to grab a bottle of the standard fare.  That was my first mistake. My second mistake was taking an inattentive big sip right after the first pour.  Fire! Boiling Water! Oak branch to the face! Tears! Burning in my nose!  Ugh!  My third mistake was thinking it would mellow with a little time.  Nope!  I've finally given up, and mixed this with a bit of Eagle Rare and water, and it's ok.  Similar to Wild Turkey 101, but not as smooth or as sweet. There are a lot of better options at this price point, to include the aforementioned Wild Turkey 101. I won't be buying this again.
Honey, peanut,vanilla & oak in the back.
Delicious, great proof and solid bourbon.  Runs $50 in NC and consider that a good price point.
Sweet, nutty, woody. Smoother than I would expect for 120 proof with a few drops of water added. I will buy more.
Smells great and is a great pour, love the 120 proof.
Very rich with a lot of balanced sweetness. Love it!
Among and vanilla nose, spicy on the tongue with a slow Oakley finish. Nice.

Full body flavor! The nose is full of oak and peanuts. The palate is thick with more oak and peanut with a hint of maple syrup. The finish is long and warm, giving you a nice Kentucky hug all the way down.

Note: prefer scotch and Irish whiskey in general so I regularly handicap bourbon.  Think it’s too sweet and simple. That being said, This is a nice whisky. It’s pretty transparent about what it is and what it’s trying to be: vanilla, maple syrup, and spice. Warms you up.

Sweet maple, ethanol, oak char, sour mash and red hots.  Palate is smooth at first and slightly viscous, then a sting accompanied by the same elements in the nose with a little leather early finish and a lasting sweet and spicy finish.  This is a serious co tender for those who can’t get their hands on the slightly hotter Stagg Jr.
Well rounded, full bodied bourbon. I feel like this would be for the discerning whiskey drinker in Victorian times. It WILL get you drunk, but still tastes good.
Maple oat meal with vanilla, very warming finish

Nose - Traditional bourbon nose, heavy oak, light vanilla, grape (maybe cherry), brown sugar, buttery cinnamon, sweet burn. 

Taste - Big tongue-drying bite, wood, vanilla, caramel, finishing pleasantly with a nice cinnamon send-off.

All the standard bourbon flavors, but not much complexity. Solid bourbon that covers the essentials well.
Knob Creek is quickly becoming one of my favorites...... especially this one!

Since bookers increased their prices this has been my goto high proof bourbon of choice. Works wonderfully well in an old fashioned due to the high proof and is priced fairly reasonable to justify mixing on the odd occasion.

One of my favorite whiskeys to enjoy on the rocks. The smell does well
To hide it’s strength at 120 proof. Bold flavors of caramel and vanilla, with a strong and deep taste of oak. Slight burn in the finish. Complex and always enjoyable.
Sweet smelling. Warming to the mouth and all the way down no dought from the 120 proof! No strong after taste, would be best sipped with a good cigar.
Wow, for a 120 proof the burn is minimal. Impressive robust rich flavors of vanilla, maple, and sweet woods. Great intro to high proof whiskey.
Right up in your face first sip but charred and tasty on the end

Frugal MacDoogals
Warehouse W-P
Floor F-05
Rick 046
Barreled 2/9/2005
Selected 9/4/2019
14 years, 6 months

Knob Creek Single Barrel 9YR

NOSE: An overall Musty Quality. Raw Peanut, Savoriness, Old Oak, Dusty Barnyard, Some Light Vanilla/Caramel in the back that builds the longer it sits. The nose on the empty Glencairn is all Cinnamon. There was an odd overwhelming "mildewy" note on the first pour (think sponge that has soured) that became more of the musty quality that I noted on future pours. I have never gotten bottle of Whiskey that had gone bad (cork taint, etc), but I thought maybe this was the first. Odd.
NEAT: Thick and Clingy Mouthfeel. Oak, Cocoa Powder, Sticky Toffee & Peanut Brittle, Black Coffee with Sugar. A little Bitter Oak on the backend. A pleasant Heat/Tingle that builds on the sides of the tongue and cheeks. A respectable Kentucky Hug that blooms in the chest.Peanut, Vanilla, and Musty Oak coats the palate. The oak continues to layer and become more pronounced with each sip. VERY good.
SPLASH: A little water doesn't change much. Gives the nose a "burnt" quality. Oddly, makes it a little hotter? Sweetens the palate into Coca Cola. Takes away an of the bitter tannins that were present. Makes the Musty Oak dominant. Almost becomes like a "Double Oaked" whiskey.

Verdict: This is my first bottle of KCSiB. I had tried it a couple years ago at a family get together and remember liking it. However, it was a store pick from somewhere in Indiana and I did not have the time/opportunity to evaluate it properly. I really like Beam products that have a little extra age and proof on them. The price used to be a little of a stumbling block for me, but with HMcK10, 4RSiB, and others cresting the $40 mark it is actually becoming a decent buy.

Nose =   Cinnamon, Red Hot Candy, Pollen
Palate =  More cinnamon & red hot candies, nice spicy note

Nose: Carmel and reminiscent of an old farm hay barn. 
Taste: sweet start, but then has some strong spice flavor to it. Good amount of heat
I like the 100 proof and I love this one even more.  Sweet, spicy and pleasant heat to it.
Love the burn. For the price and proof. I am a big fan.
Full and complex. Drinks much smoother than the proof would suggest.

Aroma - Butterscotch, Caramel Corn, Clove with hints of Fresh Oak
Texture - Silky
Flavor - Vanilla and Apple Pie with hints of Nutmeg and Char
Finish - Long and Glorious...lots of Cherry Cordial into subtle Oak
Aroma - Classic Bourbon Vanilla and oak / Taste - instant heat mixed with leather and peppercorn. Dark fruits mix towards the end. / Finish- Cherry. Lots and lots of Cherry. Possibly Cherrywood, too.
11 year store pick. Cinnamon, vanilla, oak, and a hint of that signature Beam nuttiness.

As I am maturing in tasting notes I’m lowering my score not because it’s any worse but because I have more flavor profile info. Aroma is mostly spicy and tingles the nose. Some vanilla sweetness as you take nose away. Palette is warm and toasted not charred or Smoked. Finishes warm, sweet, and balanced.

Nose - oak- corn - vanilla 
P- licorice - smooth 
Finish- Carmel- cherry - flat and warm finish 
Solid whiskey- especially for price point
Sweet nose dried fruit.  Sweet up front with a medium finish that has slight spice and dryness. Really smooth neat

(Added a cube of ice). A nice sweet nose that forebears what is coming next. The heat hits your palate with a bomb of vanilla and oak. Takes a bit of getting used to. The finish for the win as the oak flavors stick around for a while and coat your mouth. Helps to wash it down with a drink of water.
First pour was vanilla note and charred more than toasty. Warm subtle finish. After some air caramel and toasty oaks and warm/spicy. Barrel pick tasting.

Knob Creek Single Barrel Reserve 9 Year is my first try at Knob Creek and it did not disappoint whatsoever. I did find it rather difficult to remove the wax to open the bottle, but once the corked was pulled, the aromas were quite wonderful. Knob Creek Single Barrel Reserve is matured for 9 long years using new American white oak casks in Clermont, KY. Knob Creek Single Barrel Reserve 9 Year is made of 75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley and bottled at 120 proof/60% ABV making it one of the better high proof bourbons I have tasted. However, the bourbon is more enjoyable with water added which brings out more robust flavors, aromas, and only enhances the balance.

Color: Fantastic Amber Gold

On the nose are hints of maple sweetness, vanilla, charred oak, honey, and a heavy aroma of cinnamon spice. Following is a warming, rich and creamy vanilla taste on the palate with hints of pepper, cinnamon spice, and oak with a pleasant balance of sweetness, spice and a nice complexity. The 60% ABV is calmed a bit by the rich vanilla sweetness. The finish is long continuing its warmth with hints of brown sugar, caramel, some baking spices, and has a slight leatheriness to it.
Toasted caramel. Not much black cherry. Heat and oak at the back end.

Wonderful nose for a 120 proof bourbon. Slight ethanol but I’ve noticed more on lower proof drinks. Dark brown sugar and vanilla tickles the nose like I’m starting a batch of cookies.
Very full and rich on the palate. The higher proof is evident but it’s not distracting. It helps bring out the brown sugar, vanilla, as well as oak.
The finish lingers in a good way due to the ethanol. The oak sticks around along with a nice spice.

Drinking an original non-store pick. On the nose, I get strong notes of vanilla, caramel, and oak char with lighter floral notes, maraschino cherry, red apple, roasted peanuts, brown sugar, and maple syrup. The taste doesn't match the nose completely and in comparison presents a much stronger nuttiness, and tobacco note. The brown sugar/ maple syrup note evolves into a unison dense molasses note.  The lighter fruit notes on the nose get buried for the darker sweet notes on the taste. The finish is long, somewhat dry, and barrel forward with baking spice on the back end. Really enjoy this bourbon but it is one that you have to be in the mood for.
Pretty firey finish; not my style. 120 proof and burns the whole way down.
Baking spice on the nose with loads of banana on the palate. Surprisingly smooth at 120 proof!  Oak throughout but really apparent in a long finish.

Neat. Opened two months.  Found this all store pick from Party Source stashed in the back of my bar.  13 year from April 2018.  My first impression was just okay but I didn’t have a chance for a review at the time.  

Nose is quite dark, cinnamon and baking spice bomb.  It’s a hot one too, can’t get too deep or the alcohol gator bites my nose.  Caramel and oak.   I’ll call this average like my first impression but there is a note I really like.  Like charred marshmallow or meringue, like if you pull out a torch and do it to a baked Alaska.  I like that note.

Bit watery, not as thick and vicious.  All cinnamon, baking spices and oak again.  Not a fan of this one.  First impression is holding true.  It’s bitter.  Drying in a bad way.  Cotton mouth.

Barrel 6779 is just not a winner for me.  Least favorite Knob Creek store pick I have had.  I’ll see if I can mix with it.  I usually never open another Knob Creek until the current one is done.  May have to make an exception on this one.  Bah.

Fruit and some spice to the nose.  Super smooth.  I expected more bite upfront to let me know I was drinking whiskey.  Great to sip all evening.  Don’t let the smoothness fool you!  It is 120 proof!  It will eventually pack a wallup!😊
Beautiful nose...sweet and robust. Bursting with bold flavors and nice finish. Hides its 120 proof well. A fine, enjoyable bourbon!

Neat. Neck pour.  Store pick - Gallenstein Selection 22, 15 year 4 months!  Might be my oldest Knob Creek yet.  Hmmm, brighter than I was expecting on the nose for being this old.  It’s cherry and vanilla leading.  Nutmeg, cinnamon.  Barrel char.  I’d have a tough time guessing the age on this blind.  The color is dark but it is bright initially.  

I let it sit for a bit and the caramel is emerging.  It’s that hard caramel that my grandma carried in her purse.  Worthington’s right?  The oak is more there as well.  This one may change significantly now that it is opened.  

Rich and creamy, cinnamon and brown sugar take of the mouth instantly.  Zero Beam nuttiness.  Not even a hint.  I might mistake this for Buffalo Trace it is that off profile.  Cherry and even a slight hint of orange.  So sweet.  Super bright and rich vanilla.  Some caramel coming out too.  The oak only shows up on the very back end and it’s just a hint.  The more I sit with it, I start getting cola even.  Cherry cola.

Man, this is a good pick and I needed a good pick.  Last Knob I cracked sucked.  This one comes roaring back.  Shocked by the flavor profile.  A cherry forward, zero nuttiness Knob Creek?  A 15 year with only a hint of oak?  I may compare this later to EHT Barrel Proof later.  It is more in line with than than a Beam product.  So strange but utterly delicious.
Great Knob Creek flavor amped up a bit and smoother than the flagship. Vanilla, caramel and butterscotch with some heat.
Counting this bottle as my SiB store pick
Not as happy with this as single barrel

Was a little disappointed with this. First pour all i could focus on was the burn. I added a few drops of water to it and that really tamed it to allow me to actually taste it. Its not bad, but it seems pretty basic. And at $50 a bottle theres so many others in that price point i would rather drink.

These notes are from a 14.5 year old store pick from Stateline Elite in South Carolina.  Marshmallow/vanilla, oak, white pepper.  Caramel sneaks in at the end along with more oak and pepper that linger for a pleasantly long time.  I love old Knob Creek picks.  This one is no different.  Not the best I've had but very enjoyable.
